facts.text: The suit properties are the stridhana properties of Barji.
Barji died in September 1950. Her husband Patu Ram predeceased her around 1904.
Patu Ram's father Bool Chand and brothers Tulsi Ram, Behari Lal and Hira Lal predeceased Barji.
Patu Ram and Barji had a son Jugal Kishore who predeceased Patu Ram, leaving widow Bindri who died in 1931 with no children.
Radha Kishan, the adopted son of Patu Ram and Barji, died about 20 years before Barji's death, leaving widow (defendant No. 6) and children including defendants Nos. 1 to 3 through another wife.
Radha Kishan's son Roshanlal died a few months before Barji's death. His daughter Balwanti predeceased Barji leaving children defendants 4 and 5.
Tulsi Ram's son Prahlad Rai predeceased Barji leaving widow defendant No. 8 and son defendant No. 7.
By the time of Barji's death, all children of Behari Lal and Hira Lal had died but some had children and grandchildren.
After Barji's death, properties came into possession of defendant No. 6.

Defendant No. 1 sued for possession claiming she and sisters are preferential heirs; Amar Nath not impleaded, application rejected; dispute referred to arbitration which upheld claim of defendants Nos. 1 to 3.
Amar Nath (plaintiff) brought present suit claiming exclusive entitlement to suit properties.
Trial court accepted claim of defendants Nos. 1 to 3.
High Court held plaintiff exclusively entitled as nearest heir.
Properties are not sulka and Barji was married in approved form.

legal_issues.text: whether the daughters of a pre-deceased son of a Hindu Woman are entitled to succeed to her stridhana?

petitioner_arguments.text: After son's son come son's daughters. Alternatively, expression 'sons son' includes son's daughter.
List in Mitakshara is illustrative not exhaustive; 'without issue' means without progeny including son's daughter; propinquity is test so husband's brother's son cannot prefer over son's daughters.
In view of Hindu Woman's Rights to Property Act XVIII of 1937, defendants 1 to 3 are nearer heirs.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Woman's Rights to Property Act, 1937

respondent_arguments.text: Rules of succession in paragraph 147 of Mulla's Principles of Hindu Law are exhaustive; defendants Nos. 1 to 3 not entitled; plaintiff is preferential heir as nearest in degree.

court_reasoning.text: Proceed on basis that properties are stridhana of Barji married in approved form; order of succession in para 147 applies if correct and exhaustive.
Rules based on Yajnyawalcya and elaborated in Mitakshara (Colebrooke translation); after items 1-7 (son's son), goes to husband then his heirs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Colebrooke translation accurate, relied by Judicial Committee and High Courts.

court_reasoning.text: Reject contention that list illustrative or 'progeny' includes son's daughter beyond specified; opposed to commentaries and century of decisions; children do not take as body.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Propinquity not sole test for stridhana succession.

court_reasoning.text: 'Sons son' does not include son's daughter as daughters daughter precedes daughters son.
Cases cited by petitioners (Patna HC on maiden, Bali Kesserbai on sapinda) not relevant; 1937 Act applies only to separate property of Hindu male, not female's stridhana.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confirmed by Annagouda case on similar Act 11 of 1929.

holdings.text: Daughters of pre-deceased son not entitled to succeed to stridhana; succession follows exhaustive order in para 147 of Mulla; after son's son, to husband then his heirs; plaintiff exclusively entitled as nearest heir.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhimacharya Bin Venkappacharya v. Ramcharya Bin Bhimacharya
precedents_cited.relevance: Translation of Mitakshara accords with Colebrooke.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kumar Raghava Surendra Sahi v Babui Lachmi Kuer
precedents_cited.relevance: Relates to stridhana of maiden, not married woman.
On scope of placita 9 regarding sapindas, not on issue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Annagouda Nathgouda Patil v. Court of Wards
precedents_cited.relevance: Act 11 of 1929 (similar to 1937 Act) does not apply to stridhana of Hindu female.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Woman's Rights to Property Act, XVIII of 1937
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies only to separate property of Hindu male dying intestate, not to stridhana of Hindu female.

statutes_cited.name: Act 11 of 1929
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar to 1937 Act; governs only separate property of Hindu male, not female's property.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Punjab High Court judgment holding plaintiff Amar Nath exclusively entitled to Barji's stridhana as nearest heir among husband's heirs; claims of defendants Nos. 1 to 3 and other contesting defendants rejected.
outcome.relief_granted: Plaintiff exclusively entitled to suit properties

key_quotes.text: The question of law that arises for decision in these appeals by certificate is whether the daughters of a pre-deceased son of a Hindu Woman are entitled to succeed to her stridhana?
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is not well settled that stridhana of a Hindu woman governed by Mitakshara passes in the order mentioned in Mitakshara and the children of the deceased woman do not take the same as a body either jointly or as tenants-in-common.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on exhaustive nature of succession order.

key_quotes.text: Propinquity is not the sole or even the principal test in the matter of succession to stridhana.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument based on nearness of blood.
